synchronicity_analysis.but: Name is SCARY, contributes to stigma

name_impact_assessment.negative: Harsh, foreign, scary → massive stigma → treatment avoidance
name_impact_assessment.net_effect: NEGATIVE - name contributes to poor outcomes via stigma

name_impact_assessment.positive: Familiar word, lower stigma than schizophrenia, higher treatment seeking
name_impact_assessment.negative: Still somewhat stigmatized, 'depressed' used colloquially reduces seriousness
name_impact_assessment.net_effect: MODERATE POSITIVE - soft name enables treatment seeking

pubmed_data.search_query: "Major Depressive Disorder" OR "MDD" OR "Depression" OR "Clinical Depression"

phonetic_analysis.name_origin: Borderline between neurosis and psychosis (outdated concept)

name_impact_assessment.positive: None - universally regarded as poor naming
name_impact_assessment.negative: Vague, outdated concept, high stigma even among clinicians, 'borderline' sounds dismissive
name_impact_assessment.net_effect: VERY NEGATIVE - name contributes to underfunding and poor outcomes
name_impact_assessment.movement: Active patient advocacy to rename BPD

name_change_impact.funding_increase: 48x from Shell Shock to PTSD era
name_change_impact.causality: Likely bidirectional (name helped, but Vietnam advocacy also key)
name_change_impact.lesson: Medical naming reduces stigma, increases legitimacy → funding → treatment

disorders.notes: PTSD naming shows power of good nomenclature - changed outcomes for millions

name_issues.problem_1: Very long full name → everyone uses acronym
name_issues.problem_3: Two subtypes in one name (inattentive vs hyperactive conflated)
name_issues.advocacy_for_rename: Executive Function Disorder, Attention Regulation Disorder

disorders.name_impact: MIXED - acronym works clinically, but 'deficit' frame stigmatizing
